title: For Sale:  ODDBALL NUMBERS MATCHING German Nazi K98 AR43/BYF44/FN bolt late WWII 8mm
postcontent: EMAIL FOR MANY MORE PICTURES of this WWII German Nazi K98  late war rifle, code AR 43 receiver with BYF 44 Oberndorf final parts and assembly at Oberndorf.  Bolt-receiver-floorplate-trigger guard-stock are numbers matching.  Receiver top final acceptance stamp #135 MO stamped over #26 MB.  All other stamps are MO #135, except bolt root is subcontractor #140 FN yet also matching serial number to receiver, so the bolt was made in Nazi occupied Belgium then shipped back to Germany.  A knowledgeable K98 collector sent me this recent information. A 1944 dated barrel could not be on a rifle made in 1943, and Mauser Oberndorf did not supply ordnance spares in 1944. It is an MB (ar) receiver, but it was final assembled at MO (byf), the stock final and the top final of the receiver show that it was made in 1944 at MO (byf), the barrel means it was not assembled in 1943. It is not uncommon to find component sharing between MO & MB, or for that matter MO (byf) sub-contracting to other firms.  The bolt body was actually an FN part, also part of MO parent company (DWM) at the time. You can find FN bolts in both MO (byf) and MB (ar) rifles.  The bolt body was made in occupied Belgium under Nazi supervision at FN, then shipped back to Germany to be used in this run of rifles- yet the bolt is serial number matching, stamped with receiver s/n when assembled at Oberndorf.  It is unusual as this type of make up is not seen usually on an AR/43 stamped rifle, but almost all AR/44 are just like this rifle. They are hard rifles to find matching & original. This is almost certainly an early 1944 BYF assembled gun, due to the manner in which the trigger guard and stock are marked - an AR/43 wouldn't mark the floorplate like this. Code deciphers to AR 43 1943 Mauser AG Borsigwalde. This was a battlefield pickup brought home by a GI and later sporterized.  the stock was cut back to lower band, and the top handguard removed.  Otherwise it is NUMBERS MATCHING including the stock, bolt, floorplate, trigger guard, firing pin, bolt shroud, cocking piece, rear sight base and ladder.  This gun is a perfect candidate for a restoration.  The stock has been burned on the left side in the wrist area and below the thumb notch.  The gun functions 100% and is very accurate.  The story is the gun was picked up from a burned up dead Wehrmacht German soldier.  The bore is nearly perfect and would be mirror if cleaned.  I have not cleaned the barrel thoroughly with a brush and solvent.  Add a complete stock and handguard and upper band, and you have a high dollar numbers matching K98.  This is a scarce gun with these stamps on it and numbers matching.  PRICE $600 plus $35 s/h east coast, $45 west coast, California $50, Alaska and Hawaii $75 shipping.
